Award.AbstractNarration:
GHz PHONONIC CRYSTAL DEVICES

Abstract

Objective:

This proposal targets the development of a new class of GHz nanoscale phononic crystal (PC) devices that will be employed to understand and engineer the fundamental properties of low loss acoustic materials at the nanoscale, demonstrate acoustic functionalities such as tunneling, waveguiding and multiplexing and synthesize miniaturized radio frequency (RF) signal processors that are not attainable with state-of-the-art micro/nano mechanical (M/NEMS) resonators.

Intellectual Merit: The main merit of this proposal consists in devising a transformative class of acoustic devices simultaneously capable of high Q, direct matching to 50 Ã™ and unprecedented functionalities such as frequency multiplexing in a significantly reduced form factor than what is currently possible with RF components. Furthermore, the project will enable some transformative advancement at the fundamental physics level by developing experimental tools for the understanding of phonon-phonon interactions at frequencies close to and above the phonon relaxation time.

Broader Impact: The PI will be involved in organizing educational activities with local high schools in Philadelphia, with special attention to underrepresented minorities. The collaborative effort between the PI's laboratory and the West Philadelphia schools will allow high school students doing research in the PI's laboratory to learn more about cutting-edge science and technology. Undergraduate students will be involved in research activities via research positions and summer REU programs. The fundamental discoveries enabled by this project will be included in the current graduate course the PI is teaching. Finally, the PI plans to involve the general public by presenting his research findings at the Penn Nanoday.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has investigated the use of microfabrication techniques for the making of phononic crystal (PnC) structures in thin films of aluminum nitride (AlN) and lithium niobate (LN). Theoretical and experimental methods for the design and making of PC-based devices at the nanoscale have been developed. Thanks to the miniaturized dimensions of the PC structures acoustic cavities and filters operating from 100s of MHz to GHz frequencies were experimentally demonstrated.  The same PnC building blocks were monolithically integrated with electro-acoustic piezoelectric transducers made out of thin films of AlN and LN. The latter has specifically enabled the synthesis of transducers with very high electromechanical coupling, hence permitting efficient coupling of electrical energy into the phononic structures.  Intellectually, the project has laid the foundation for the development of nanoscale phononic (acoustic) devices that are the basic building blocks of extremely compact high frequency spectral processors. Similarly, these demonstrations have furthered the theoretical and experimental analysis of phonon scattering and bragg resonances in nanoscale devices and helped understating how to synthesize novel functions such as acoustic tunneling and slowing sound.

Beyond directly impacting the field of radio frequency signal processing, acoustics and phononics, these engineered meta-structures will definitely benefit other applications. PnCs could be used as basic building blocks for the demonstration of acoustic matching and focusing in ultrasonic transducers, optical cooling in opto-acoustic devices, high thermal conductivity materials, and loss free suspensions for micro and nanomechanical devices such as gyroscopes, accelerometers and resonators. 

The project has enabled the training of two PhDs and two undergraduate students in the area of phononics, acoustics, and electronics. The students have published papers and participated in international conferences and workshops. The PI has organized and given workshops and tutorials on the topics of acoustic resonators, phononic structures, resonant sensors and optomechanical devices at international conferences targeting a broad audience of engineers, and academic and industry researchers.
